text: I want to take a hard left turn here and actually go back to our discussion because we veered off in a wonderful tangent. But I want to go back to our discussion a little bit on the more practical nature of tail risk hedging and here in particular in equity markets. One of the potential changes we have seen over the last couple of years is different dominant agents emerge in the option space. So there's what I would call sort of the thousand duck sized horses in the form of socially levered retail traders. They've sort of disappeared recently, but certainly a potentially large dominant agent as a collective in the last couple of years. And then as maybe a counterexample, the big horse sized duck would be the JP Morgan hedged equity fund that has very well documented role schedules and I think has something close to $20 billion in it. Both of these could potentially represent. Risks or conversely, potentially represent structural edges that hedgers could take the other side of. How do you think about monitoring for the emergence or disappearance of these dominant players and structural edges within the option space?
